chapter.title: A "How-to" for this book
chapter.para: First, thank you for buying this book. It's only through the interest of readers like you that a project like this is possible.

We wrote this book because Asterisk doesn't come with an instruction manual. Many of the resources recommended by members of the Asterisk community are in the form of wikis and websites which are inconsistently updated and often contain information that is incorrect. We wanted this book to serve as that missing manual to Asterisk. In other words, we wanted to create the kind of book we were looking for: a readable text that can be read in chapter order or used as a handbook.

section.title: What is Asterisk?
section.para: Asterisk is a telephone system, but different. It's not hardware, it's software that can be downloaded via the Internet. The only thing you need to get started is an ordinary PC, the Asterisk software, this book and interest.

Asterisk works with a variety of technologies, including analog telephone, ISDN telephone and VoIP. With an Asterisk system, an employee can work at home with an IP phone and make calls in the office system as though she were in the office. The possibilities are limitless, both to extend the functionality of your system and to save money. Telephony remains sophisticated, however, and a move to Asterisk is not without its challenges. You need to become comfortable and familiar with both the technology and with Asterisk itself.
Let's explore the difference between Asterisk and a conventional telephone system by way of an analogy from childhood.

Most of us grew up with toys of two basic types. With the first type, everything came "ready to go", as it would in the case of model cars or teddy bears. The second type offered some room for variation and creativity, as in the case of Lego blocks. With the "ready to go" toys, the fun was right there when you opened the package, but you were limited to play as conceived by the toy company. With the blocks, you didn't get a finished toy. To get one, you had to come up with a design and then build it, but you could build anything you wanted, within the limitations of the pieces available.

That, in a nutshell, is exactly how it is with Asterisk. It is delivered in pieces. Think of a design, and suddenly anything is possible. Best of all, you can improve the resulting "toy" any time with new pieces.
Both types have their pros and cons.

para.emphasis: The main advantages of a conventional telephone system are:

listitem.para: Unpack and you're done! You can start making calls almost immediately.
Limited instructions are required.

para.emphasis: The main disadvantages of a conventional telephone system are:

listitem.para: Expansion is usually very expensive, and not all functions are supported or even available.
It's a black box. You have no way to find out what's happening inside, which can be vital when troubleshooting.

para.emphasis: The main advantages of a software-based Asterisk system:

listitem.para: You can build new solutions to problems any time. All you need is an appropriate design.
You can combine components to create new systems and solutions.
You start with: a bunch of components. Building them into a system requires some patience.
You need some skill. Success doesn't come quickly.

section.title: Who Should Read this Book?
section.para: Not everybody has to start at square one, nor does every interested person want to become an Asterisk professional. This book is intended for both and will be a valuable reference for beginners, novices and experts alike.

section.title: The Beginner
section.para: Absolute beginners should read the book in chapter order, since the chapters build on each other. You can start with and read until the end. At a minimum, read through and and you'll be able to put together more complex telephone systems. If you have programming experience, you might try getting started with .
Beginners often have questions about what equipment is best to buy and which service to order, so we've provided this brief FAQ for those who need some guidance.

question.para: How do I choose a VoIP provider? What do I need to watch out for?

answer.para: When starting out, choose a SIP provider that offers free accounts so that you can gather some experience. Which provider you choose for the long term can depend on many factors. Here are but a few things to consider:

listitem.para: Does the provider offer only SIP or also IAX? Do you need IAX?
How good is the support? For VoIP, good support can be critical.
How is the pricing? This is not always obvious.

question.para: Which digital interface card should I use?

answer.para: Get comfortable using only SIP trunks and extensions to start. Once you understand the dialplan and contexts, you can proceed to the ISDN-Kapitel, where there are tips for choosing the right digital card for your application.

question.para: Which phones are standard and what do they cost?

answer.para: There aren't really "standard" phones. You have several options:

listitem.para: A SIP telephone (this is the simplest option)
An analog telephone using an ATA (analog telephone adapter) connected to the network
An analog telephone using an FXS port on an analog interface card
A digital telephone (such as a Nortel Meridian phone) using a suitable digital telephone adapter connected to the network

An ISDN phone using a port on a T1 card. These phones are sold almost exclusively in Europe where ISDN termination is much more common. Before the arrival of VoIP, they were the most feature-filled devices; nowadays they are functionally indistinguishable from VoIP phones and can cost three times as much. If you have the option, it's best to go with a SIP telephone.

Exotic constructs. You can, for example, connect a channel bank to a T1 interface card and attach analog phones to the channel bank. Such constructions are generally useful in retrofit applications. If you're starting from scratch, keep it simple.

answer.para: As for pricing, this changes constantly. There are countless suppliers. Inquire frequently and compare. Quality VoIP hardware is becoming more and more affordable.

section.title: The Journeyman
section.para: It would be impossible to guess what an intermediate Asterisk user knows and doesn't know. Even if you have good command of a subject there are always aspects to it that might be new. If you have some practical experience, you could skip or just skim through it. Personally, though, we can only recommend that you read it anyway. It almost always pays off.
Leaf through the additional chapters afterwards. In writing the book we focused on practical examples. Just reading the example configurations can give you some new ideas.

section.title: The Expert
section.para: You can skip and just go on a discovery tour of the book. There are numerous practical examples you can employ immediately in your own practice; the examples may even give you a few new ideas.

Beyond that, we hope this book will be a valuable reference. All the important application and function parameters are included and explained, usually with working examples. We placed particular emphasis on comparisons between the different Asterisk versions (1.2 to 1.6).

section.title: Updates and versions of the book
section.para: This book is being developed as a typical open source project would be. What you are holding in your hands is a printed version of the stable branch. Updates and errata can be found at http://www.the-asterisk-book.com.

You'll find the current SVN version there. That'll be the next edition, but for now it is on the bleeding edge. The procedures contained there may not have been tested and may not even be recommended. Therefore, a warning: use that material only if you know what you're doing.

section.title: Reader Contributions and Feedback
section.para: We intended this book to be a living text. This is why it was released under the GNU Free Documentation License (see ). This is why you can find the most current version of the book at http://www.the-asterisk-book.com.

If you have suggestions for improvements, include it in an e-mail to stefan.wintermeyer@amooma.de. If you have more comprehensive improvements to contribute, attach them in ASCII text format or directly in DocBook format to your e-mail.
Thanks in advance for your interest in this project!
There are numerous ways you can help support the project, from providing a positive review for the book on Amazon.com, all the way to contributing a chapter that addresses a specific problem.

This book will never be perfect and also never really "finished". The subject is too complex and changes too rapidly. Remember that you can always find the most current (and most bleeding-edge) version of the book at http://www.the-asterisk-book.com. Accordingly, this FAQ is intended for the web version of the book. If you find an error in the book, please check the website first to see if the error has already been fixed.

question.para: I tried something from the book, but it didn't work as described. Should I report this?

answer.para: Yes, absolutely! When reporting, provide the URL and any relevant error messages.

question.para: How can I report an error?

answer.para: The easiest way is with an e-mail to the author, Stefan Wintermeyer: stefan.wintermeyer@amooma.de.

question.para: In what format is the book written?

answer.para: The source for the book is written in DocBook format. You can learn more about DocBook at http://www.docbook.org.

question.para: Why isn't there a wiki, where anybody can make changes?

answer.para: First: Because the book is printed, a print deadline has to be set. A constantly changing text makes it impossible for the editors to keep up and keep the resulting printed material consistent. Second: There are already numerous Asterisk wikis on the Internet; their chief advantage (quick and easy changes) also leads to their chief disadvantage: mountains of painfully outdated and outright incorrect information. Using DocBook and managing changes means we have a more structured, more readable text that is as accurate as human beings can make it.
If the entire text were in a wiki, it would make export for printing very difficult.

question.para: What editor do I need to write in DocBook format?

answer.para: That's almost a "religious" question. Some people like emacs, others like vi. The author and contributors use XMLmind XML Editor most of the time. You can obtain it from http://www.xmlmind.com/xmleditor/.

question.para: Can I obtain the original DocBook files?

answer.para: Yes. If you have extensive changes to make, you are welcome to work on the original files. Write an e-mail to the author, Stefan Wintermeyer: stefan.wintermeyer@amooma.de.

question.para: You didn't cover XYZ! Unbelievable. It's so important! What were you thinking?

answer.para: Contact the author at stefan.wintermeyer@amooma.de and briefly describe the subject.
If you're willing to write a chapter and make it available under the GNU FDL, let Stefan know. He'll send you a sample DocBook chapter.
A script pulls the DocBook sources from the SVN and uses them to generate the HTML pages.

section.title: Further Resources
section.para: You have a problem and weren't able to find the answer in this book? Here are your options:

listitem.para: This site is dedicated to VoIP in general and to Asterisk and it offers solutions to most problems. Unfortunately, many of the articles contain errors. If you find one, fix it! The next visitor will be grateful.
IRC Channel IRC Channel

There is an Asterisk IRC channel, #asterisk at irc.freenode.net. It's sometimes possible to get a quick answer to your question there, though be warned: some of the channel participants have a low tolerance for laziness. You improve your chances of success by thinking your question through carefully. Generally, the motto "explaining your problem is half the solution" applies.
If you are new to IRC, you can learn more about it at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_Relay_Chat.
Mailing lists Mailing lists

The Digium mailing lists are not for everybody. The list has very high volume and a new list user can be quickly overwhelmed. Still, it has a few significant advantages: it's read by Digium staff and they often answer questions. You can also get more detailed answers than is typical for IRC. You can find out how to subscribe to the mailing lists at http://www.asterisk.org/support/ and http://lists.digium.com/.
E-Mail Stefan Wintermeyer (stefan.wintermeyer@amooma.de)
If all else fails, you can always try contacting the author. Just be warned that he gets a lot of mail and may not get to your question for several days.
